chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;'s translation component. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy this &PRODNAME; component, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.
This handbook is focused on one &PRODNAME; component. Other &PRODNAME; components are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: Introduction to the Translation Component of &PRODNAME;
chapter.para: Translation changes the format of a request or response so that it meets the expectations of the service or client that receives it. You can use &PRODNAME;'s translation filter to transform XML into JSON. You can also use &PRODNAME;'s translation filter to transform JSON into JSONx, which is formatted like XML. Whether or not you transform the body of the message into another format, you can use the translation filter to remove elements that are invalid for the receiver or to add elements that are required by the receiver. This means you can choose components to combine in a stack based on their core features; without the &PRODNAME; translation filter, incompatible standards for output and input might make some otherwise-beneficial combinations impractical.

To use &PRODNAME; for translation, you must add the translation component as a filter in your &PRODNAME; configuration. You can learn more about customizing your &PRODNAME; configuration by reading the Repose Deployment Handbook and by examining a basic system model configuration in GitHub.

&PRODNAME; uses Saxon 9.3 to perform translation by applying XSLT 2.0 stylesheets to requests and responses. In addition to adding the translation filter to your configuration, you must create and customize your stylesheets to define the changes you wish the translation filter to perform.

The &PRODNAME; translation component performs two categories of behavior:
changing the format of a message (translating between JSON and XML)
changing the content of a message (adding or deleting elements)

tip.para: Translation processing is controlled by translation.cfg.xml; to change your translation configuration, edit translation.cfg.xml. You can see an annotated example of translation.cfg.xml in .

chapter.title: Configuration

tip.para: Before attempting to customize your translation configuration and its stylesheets, familiarize yourself with the basic &PRODNAME; concepts and deployment methods in our Getting Started document.

chapter.para: The translation component obtains its configuration, including its API endpoint, from a file named translation.cfg.xml. We have included an annotated example of a valid translation.cfg.xml in this chapter.

To change your translation configuration, edit translation.cfg.xml at any time. Within translation.cfg.xml, you can specify which stylesheets are to be applied under what circumstances; as with the translation configuration, you can edit your stylesheets to make changes at runtime.

section.title: Customizing a Translation Stylesheet
section.para: The &PRODNAME; translation component uses XSLT 2.0 stylesheets to process messages. One place to learn the basics of XLST is the XSLT Elements Reference.

You can create and combine multiple stylesheets to accomplish the translation you require. To make stylesheets active within your &PRODNAME; configuration, specify the stylesheets in translation.cfg.xml as shown at You can store a stylesheet as a standalone file or you can embed the XSL style specification within translation.cfg.xml.

chapter.title: Changing a Message's Format
chapter.para: You can translate an XML message from JSON, Atom, or HTML. You can translate a JSON message to JSONx, which resembles XML; you can also translate a JSONX message to JSON.

section.title: Translating XML to JSON
section.para: You can translate XML to JSON.

You can use cURL to confirm that you have the stylesheet and the translation configuration set up correctly; if they are correct, the XML input you provide will be echoed as JSON.

section.title: Translating JSON to JSONx
section.para:
You can use the &PRODNAME; translation component to turn all elements found in JSON input into XML-shaped JSONx output.
JSON Input Becomes JSONx Output
Input: JSON Translation Output: JSONx
{"field1": "value1", "field2": "value2"}
Apply stylesheet as defined in translation configuration.
<json:object xmlns:json="http://www.ibm.com/xmlns/prod/2009/jsonx" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <json:string name="field1">value1</json:string> <json:string name="field2">value2</json:string> </json:object>

To make this possible, create a stylesheet to define the transformation, and call for that stylesheet in your translation configuration, translation.cfg.xml. To create the result shown above, fully translating JSON input to JSONx output, create a stylesheet and a translation configuration that includes the stylesheet as shown below:
Stylesheet Applied by Translation Configuration: Translating JSON to JSONx
Stylesheet: identity.xsl Translation Configuration: translation.cfg.xml

In the stylesheet, <xsl:copy-of select="."/> asks for a copy of the entire document. In the translation configuration, the stylesheet is called for by its name (identity.xsl) ; content-type identifies the expected input as JSON and translated-content-type identifies the expected output as XML.

You can use cURL to confirm that you have the stylesheet and the translation configuration set up correctly; if they are correct, the JSON input you provide will be echoed as JSONx.
cURL Confirming Translation from JSON to JSONx

section.title: Translating JSON to JSONx to JSON
section.para: You can use the &PRODNAME; translation component to turn all elements found in JSON input into XML-shaped JSONx output and then back into JSON. For details about translating JSON to JSONx, see .

You can use cURL to confirm that you have the stylesheet and the translation configuration set up correctly; if they are correct, the JSON input you provide will be echoed as JSON.
cURL Confirming Translation from JSON to JSONx to JSON

chapter.title: Changing a Message's Content
chapter.para: You can use the translation component to rewrite the same message with some content added or removed.

section.title: Adding Content to a Message
section.para: You can use the &PRODNAME; translation component to add an element to a copy of an incoming message so that element is included when the copy is forwarded. XML Input Becomes Shorter XML Output Input: Original XML Message Translation Output: Shortened XML Message Stuff Apply stylesheets as defined in translation configuration. Stuff

To make this possible, create stylesheets to define the transformations, and call for those stylesheets in your translation configuration, translation.cfg.xml. To create the result shown above, deleting the remove-me element, create a stylesheet asking for a complete copy, (identify.xsl), another stylesheet asking for addition of specific content to the copy (add-element.xsl), and a translation configuration that includes both stylesheets as shown below:
Stylesheets Applied by Translation Configuration: Adding Content to an XML Message
Stylesheets: identity.xsl + add-element.xsl Translation Configuration: translation.cfg.xml

In the identify.xsl stylesheet, <xsl:copy-of select="."/> asks for a copy of the entire document. In the add-element.xsl stylesheet, add-me asls for anything marked with that wrapper to be added to the message as another wrapper around the entire message. In the translation configuration, the stylesheets are called for by their names (identity.xsl and add-element.xsl); content-type identifies the expected input as XHTML+XML and translated-content-type identifies the expected output as XML; code-regex="2[\d]{2} applies this stylesheet chain only to responses with a status code in the range of 2xx.

You can use cURL to confirm that you have the stylesheet and the translation configuration set up correctly; if they are correct, the element you asked to add will be echoed in the output.
cURL Confirming Addition to Message

section.title: Deleting Content from a Message
section.para: You can use the &PRODNAME; translation component to delete an element from a copy of an incoming message so that element is omitted when the copy is forwarded. XML Input Becomes Shorter XML Output Input: Original XML Message Translation Output: Shortened XML Message testStuff Apply stylesheets as defined in translation configuration. Stuff

To make this possible, create stylesheets to define the transformations, and call for those stylesheets in your translation configuration, translation.cfg.xml. To create the result shown above, deleting the remove-me element, create a stylesheet asking for a complete copy, (identify.xsl), another stylesheet asking for removal of specific content from the copy (remove-element.xsl), and a translation configuration that includes both stylesheets as shown below:
Stylesheets Applied by Translation Configuration: Deleting Content from an XML Message
Stylesheets: identity.xsl + remove-element.xsl Translation Configuration: translation.cfg.xml

In the identify.xsl stylesheet, <xsl:copy-of select="."/> asks for a copy of the entire document. In the remove-element.xsl stylesheet, remove-me asls for anything marked with that wrapper to be deleted. In the translation configuration, the stylesheets are called for by their names (identity.xsl and remove-element.xsl); content-type identifies the expected input as XML and translated-content-type identifies the expected output as XML; code-regex="2[\d]{2} applies this stylesheet chain only to responses with a status code in the range of 2xx.

You can use cURL to confirm that you have the stylesheet and the translation configuration set up correctly; if they are correct, the element you asked to remove will be missing from the output.
cURL Confirming Deletion from Message
